Authors:
stephane bellafiore, Claire Jougla, Phong Vu Nguyen, Huong
Thi Mai Nguyen, Elodie Chapuis, Dat Tai Nguyen, Pascal Gantet, Malyna
Suong, Dirk De Waele, Xuyen Thi Ngo
Title:
Characterisation of the rice root-knot nematode (Meloidogyne
graminicola) populations from rice fields in Vietnam reveals
intraspecific variability
Keywords:
Intraspecific variability, Meloidogyne graminicola,
Morphometrics, Rice, SCAR, Vietnam
Abstract:
Twenty years ago the root-knot nematode (RKN), Meloidogyne
graminicola, was recognised as an important rice pathogen in South
Vietnam. Although this country is one of the most important rice
exporters worldwide, a comprehensive picture of the occurrence of M.
graminicola in Vietnam is still not available. Therefore a nematode
survey was carried out with the aim of better understanding the
geographical distribution and the genetic variability of this nematode
in Vietnam. From the fields surveyed in a range of ecosystems, 21
populations of RKN were recovered from infected rice roots. These
populations were characterised using morphometrics and pathogenicity
tests (host plant range diversity, reproduction and virulence diversity)
revealing intraspecific polymorphism. We showed that morphomeric traits
are mainly genetically heritable characters with significant differences
amongst the studied populations. A molecular study was also carried out
to identify the genetic diversity of these populations. We developed a
specific M. graminicola SCAR marker and showed that all the Vietnamese
populations belong to the species M. graminicola. Furthermore,
sequencing of the Internal Transcribed Spacer (ITS) of the rDNA genes
confirmed the M. graminicola identification. Finally, a distinctive
trait signature was found for the populations isolated from the upland
rice cultures. All together, our study reveals the prevalence and
intraspecific diversity of M. graminicola populations in Vietnam.
Further investigations, including a larger survey and the development of
new markers like microsatellites, need to be developed to explore the
genetic plasticity and evolutionary history of this species in this
region of the world
